review.title: Learning Granger Causality for Hawkes Processes
review.abstract: Learning Granger causality for general point processes is a very challenging task. In this paper, we propose an effective method, learning Granger causality, for a special but significant type of point processes --- Hawkes process. We reveal the relationship between Hawkes process's impact function and its Granger causality graph. Specifically, our model represents impact functions using a series of basis functions and recovers the Granger causality graph via group sparsity of the impact functions' coefficients. We propose an effective learning algorithm combining a maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) with a sparse-group-lasso (SGL) regularizer. Additionally, the flexibility of our model allows to incorporate the clustering structure event types into learning framework. We analyze our learning algorithm and propose an adaptive procedure to select basis functions. Experiments on both synthetic and real-world data show that our method can learn the Granger causality graph and the triggering patterns of the Hawkes processes simultaneously.

sections.text: In many practical situations, we have to deal with a large amount of irregular and asynchronous sequential data that is observed over a continuous period of time. sections.heading: 5.2. Real-world Data
sections.text: We test our algorithm on the basis of IPTV viewing data (Luo et al., 2014; 2015; 2016).The data set records the viewing behavior of 7,100 users, i.e., what and when they watch, in the IPTV system from January to November 2012. U (= 13) categories of television programs are predefined. Similar to (Luo et al., 2015), we model the viewing behavior of users through a Hawkes process in which the TV programs themselves and mutually triggering patterns exist. Thus, watching an episode of a drama would lead to watching the following episodes (self-triggering) and related messages from actors (mutual triggering).Therefore, causality among the categories depends not only on the predetermined schedules, but also on the viewing preferences of users. We capture the Granger causality of the program categories via learning functions.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: In this thesis we learn the Granger causality of Hawkes processes from the relationship between Granger causality and function functions. In combination with the rare group lasso, we propose an effective algorithm to learn the Granger causality curve of the target process. We demonstrate the robustness and rationality of our work on both synthetic and real data. In the future, we plan to expand our work and analyze the Granger causality of general point processes.

metadata.abstractText: Learning Granger causality for general point processes is a very challenging task. In this paper, we propose an effective method, learning Granger causality, for a special but significant type of point processes — Hawkes process. According to the relationship between Hawkes process’s impact function and its Granger causality graph, our model represents impact functions using a series of basis functions and recovers the Granger causality graph via group sparsity of the impact functions’ coefficients. We propose an effective learning algorithm combining a maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) with a sparsegroup-lasso (SGL) regularizer. Additionally, the flexibility of our model allows to incorporate the clustering structure event types into learning framework. We analyze our learning algorithm and propose an adaptive procedure to select basis functions. Experiments on both synthetic and real-world data show that our method can learn the Granger causality graph and the triggering patterns of the Hawkes processes simultaneously.
